Label: Features unique to one genus
Help: A few genera are so distinctive that one of these choices defines them.

Label: Length in mm
Help:
Size is often unhelpful at the genus level because there may be a considerable range among species within the genus, and even among individuals within a species.
But several genera (and the metallic sub-groups of (Lasioglossum and Halictus) are invariably small (<8mm). And some genera have no small species. E.g., Bombus is typically larger than a honeybee.

Label: Color of integument
Help: Color of the integument - irrespective of hairs.

Label: Hairiness
Help: Relative density of body hair. Check more than one option for borderline cases

Label: Among Megachilidae: unique features of Ashmeadiella.
Help: Photos: T1 anterior, mesepisternum, and apical teeth (male) of Ashmeadiella

Label: Bands of hair dorsally on the abdominal segments.
Help: When present, may be partial or complete

Label: Number of submarginal cells
Help: On the forewing, there are either two or three cells below the topmost, marginal cell.

Label: Basal vein arch
Help: An arched basal vein is a character of Halictid genera. There are species of other genera that may also appear arched, requiring additional characters to ID.

Label: 2nd Recurrent vein shape
Help: The vein below the distal submarginal cell.

Label: Hair in closed cellls
Help:
Are there hairs in the closed cells (like submarginal cells)?
(Distinguishes Eucera from Anthophora)

Label: Sex
Help: Most actively foraging bees are female

Label: Scopae: for females only
Help: A character of many females - brushes of hair that accumulate pollen.

Label: Abdominal hair bands - apical or basal
Help: This character differentiates Lasioglossum from Halictus

Label: Is there a depressed area medial to the eye?
Help: The fovea is a good character when observable, but it is often difficult to see without optimal light and magnification.

Label: Parapsidal line
Help: A feature of Megachilidae. Medial to the wing base, there is a punctate dot (Osmia)Êor a linear impression (others).
